instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no trackpad/keyboard
threads.message:
Changed trackpad and flex already. Was minor water damage but not there trackpad or keyboard areas.

keyboard has 3.3v at pin 30
and 3.4v at pin 4
trackpad has 5v pin 4 and 3.3v at pin 1

at one stage when testing pin1 on trackpad I touched ground too and it shorted and I had to replace <RESISTOR>R4808</RESISTOR> when it shorted though the keyboard stared working.
put <RESISTOR>R4808</RESISTOR> back and no keyboard again. 

Keyboard pin 5 <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no trackpad/keyboard
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no trackpad/keyboard
threads.message:
Put a new <CHIP>U4801</CHIP> on - no change
found it wasnâ€™t doing a smc reset changed <TRANSISTOR>Q4801</TRANSISTOR> <CHIP>U4850</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> started doing an smc reset but no working keyboard or trackpad. 

Smc reset has stopped working again now. Reflowed smc cause getting desperate. No change. 

So as of right now. External mouse works. No power button to turn on. No smc reset happening. Once on no track pad or keyboard still.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no trackpad/keyboard
threads.message: Randomly replacing parts without diagnosing is just adding more variables to the mix. Was power at <CHIP>U4801</CHIP> checked?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no trackpad/keyboard
threads.message:
Yeh I know better. You are exactly right. Unfortunately because I have no patience, frustration at myself and then desperation lead here..
Anyway yes 3.3v is there as well as <SIGNAL>TPAD_VBUS_EN</SIGNAL> 3.3v
Have traced all keyboard and trackpad pins back to <CHIP>U4801</CHIP> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no trackpad/keyboard
threads.message: Don't care about the keyboard, the trackpad needs to work first. Check all connection from <CHIP>U4801</CHIP> to the end of the trackpad cable so you know traces/connector/cable are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no trackpad/keyboard
threads.message: Did you perhaps plug in/disconnect the tpad while the battery was plugged in? I just had another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> come in with no tpad/kb after the last person tried hotswapping the tpad connector. I also have the issue on a 3662 where I may have plugged in the tpad while the macs battery was connected. Could 3v3(pin 1 on 3476; 22 on 3662) fry the adjacent <SIGNAL>Z2_CLKIN</SIGNAL>(pin 2 on 3476; 20 on 3662) when plugged in misaligned?
